verse_commentaries.commentary: The verse opens with אַ֥שְֽׁרֵי־, a beatitude formula that's more intensive than simple 'blessed.' The triadic progression of verbs (הָלַךְ֮/עָמָ֑ד/יָשָֽׁב) creates escalating permanence from temporary walking to permanent sitting. The three groups (רְשָׁ֫עִ֥ים/חַ֭טָּאִים/לֵ֝צִ֗ים) form a spectrum from general wickedness to active scoffing.
figurative_analysis: physical movement metaphors for moral choices
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes the fundamental binary worldview through negative definition of righteousness

verse_commentaries.commentary: The verse pivots with כִּ֤י אִ֥ם (but rather), creating sharp contrast. חֶ֫פְצ֥וֹ suggests passionate desire, not mere duty. יֶהְגֶּ֗ה is intriguing - it means 'murmur/mutter,' suggesting audible meditation. The merismus יוֹמָ֥ם וָלָֽיְלָה emphasizes totality but may also suggest continuous vocal practice.
figurative_analysis: Torah as object of erotic desire (חפץ)
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Provides positive definition of righteousness centered on Torah devotion as delight rather than obligation

verse_commentaries.commentary: The tree metaphor is remarkably specific: שָׁת֢וּל (transplanted, not naturally growing) suggests intentional cultivation. פַּלְגֵי־מָ֥יִם (channels/streams) implies irrigation systems, not random water sources. The phrase וְכֹ֖ל אֲשֶׁר־יַעֲשֶׂ֣ה יַצְלִֽיחַ broadens from agricultural to universal success. עָלֵ֥הוּ לֹֽא־יִבּ֑וֹל uses a rare verb for withering.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Develops the positive consequences of Torah devotion through agricultural metaphor of cultivation and prosperity

verse_commentaries.commentary: לֹא־כֵ֥ן creates stark negation and transition. The wicked get no extended description - just מֹּ֗ץ (chaff), the agricultural waste product. תִּדְּפֶ֥נּוּ רֽוּחַ emphasizes violent scattering by wind/spirit. The verse's brevity contrasts sharply with v.3's elaborate tree description, suggesting the wicked lack substance worthy of description.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Provides antithetical imagery to the rooted tree - emphasizing transience and vulnerability of wickedness

verse_commentaries.commentary: עַל־כֵּ֤ן signals logical consequence. לֹא־יָקֻ֣מוּ בַּמִּשְׁפָּ֑ט suggests judicial proceedings where wicked cannot 'stand' (same root as v.1 עָמָד). בַּעֲדַ֥ת צַדִּיקִֽים introduces communal dimension absent from individual focus of vv.1-4. The parallelism distinguishes רְ֭שָׁעִים from חַטָּאִ֗ים, echoing v.1's categorization.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Introduces eschatological dimension and communal identity as validation of individual righteousness

verse_commentaries.commentary: יוֹדֵ֣עַ suggests intimate knowledge, not mere awareness. The inclusio with דֶּ֣רֶךְ echoes v.1's path imagery. The asymmetry is striking: YHWH actively 'knows' the righteous way, but the wicked way simply 'perishes' (תֹּאבֵֽד) - no divine agent specified. The psalm ends with {פ} (petuhah), marking major section break in Psalter structure.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Provides theological foundation for the entire contrast - divine election and governance as ultimate reality

thematic_threads: Escalating involvement pattern: walking→standing→sitting parallels temporary→permanent engagement
Agricultural metaphor complex: cultivation (planting) → irrigation → fruit → waste (chaff) → scattering
Asymmetrical treatment: elaborate description of righteous, minimal description of wicked
Movement from individual (vv.1-4) to communal (v.5) to cosmic/divine (v.6) scope
Sound patterns emphasize contrast: liquid/soft sounds for righteous, harsh gutturals for wicked judgment
interesting_questions: Why does the psalm use שָׁתוּל (transplanted) rather than נָטַע (planted) - does this suggest conversion rather than natural righteousness?
What is the significance of יֶהְגֶּה (murmur/mutter) - does Torah study involve specific vocal practices?
Why is the description of the wicked so abbreviated compared to the elaborate righteous imagery?
How does the judicial language in v.5 (משפט, עדת) relate to the agricultural metaphors of vv.3-4?
Why does YHWH actively 'know' the righteous way but the wicked way simply 'perishes' without divine action?
What distinguishes the three categories of wicked people in v.1 (רשעים, חטאים, לצים)?
How does the merismus 'day and night' in v.2 relate to the seasonal imagery 'in its season' in v.3?
synthesis_notes:
LEXICON: Focus on הגה (meditation practices), שתול (transplanting vs planting), יודע (covenantal knowing)
CONCORDANCE: Track two-ways theology, Torah terminology, judicial assembly language
FIGURATIVE: Agricultural metaphor complex, path/way imagery, judicial standing terminology
COMMENTARY: Interpretive puzzles around transplanted trees, vocalized meditation, asymmetrical divine action
